title: RS22154
content: The Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, initiated in 1986 under GATT, concluded in 1994 with the signing of the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the WTO. The WTO Agreement, effective from January 1, 1995, requires countries to accept all agreements negotiated during the Round. This package includes GATT obligations like nondiscriminatory treatment of goods and refraining from imposing quantitative restrictions. The Uruguay Round package of agreements under the WTO includes GATT obligations such as nondiscriminatory treatment of goods, tariff limits, and dispute settlement procedures. The Uruguay Round package includes the Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU) for resolving disputes between WTO Members. The process involves consultations, panels, appeals, and adoption of reports by the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB). Non-compliance with WTO obligations must be rectified within a specified time frame. The Uruguay Round package includes the Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU) for resolving disputes between WTO Members. If a defending Member is found to have violated a WTO obligation, it must implement the decision within a "reasonable period of time." Non-compliance may lead to compensation or retaliatory measures. Congress approved the WTO Agreement in the Uruguay Round Agreement Act (URAA). The URAA, approved by Congress, addresses the legal effects of WTO agreements in the US, prohibits private remedies for alleged violations, and requires the USTR to update Congress on disputes. The URAA, approved by Congress, addresses the legal effects of WTO agreements in the US, prohibits private remedies for alleged violations, and requires the USTR to update Congress on disputes. It also imposes requirements on agencies implementing WTO decisions and specific provisions for challenged agency determinations in trade remedy proceedings. The URAA, approved by Congress, implements WTO decisions in the US, including provisions for challenged agency determinations in trade remedy proceedings. It contains necessary provisions to enforce the Uruguay Round agreements. The URAA implements WTO decisions in the US, including provisions for challenged agency determinations in trade remedy proceedings. It contains necessary provisions to enforce the Uruguay Round agreements, with domestic law superseding any inconsistent provisions of WTO agreements approved and implemented in the URAA. The URAA implements WTO decisions in the US, with domestic law superseding any inconsistent provisions of WTO agreements. Congressional or administrative action is required to implement WTO decisions challenged in the U.S. The URAA implements WTO decisions in the US, with domestic law superseding any inconsistent provisions of WTO agreements. Agreements that conflict with US law will not have effect, and US law will take precedence over WTO agreements. The URAA implements WTO decisions in the US, with domestic law superseding any inconsistent provisions of WTO agreements. US law will take precedence over WTO agreements in case of conflict. Congress has addressed potential conflicts between domestic law and prior trade agreements in a similar manner. The URAA implements WTO decisions in the US, with domestic law taking precedence over any conflicting provisions in WTO agreements. Congress has historically addressed conflicts between domestic law and prior trade agreements in a similar manner. The URAA legislative history states that implementation of WTO dispute settlement results requires legislation approved by Congress unless consistent implementation is permissible under the terms of the statute. Congress has specified procedures for agencies to comply with WTO decisions if a statute allows for consistent implementation. The URAA requires legislation approved by Congress for implementing WTO dispute settlement results, unless consistent implementation is allowed under the statute. If state law is involved in a WTO dispute, federal-state cooperation is mandated, and the USTR must collaborate with the state to develop a response. The URAA centralizes the response to adverse WTO rulings and precludes private remedies. The URAA requires federal-state cooperation to respond to adverse WTO rulings involving state law. It centralizes the response in the federal government and allows only the United States to challenge state laws domestically. The URAA allows the United States to challenge state laws domestically if they are found inconsistent with the Uruguay Round Agreements, but does not automatically preempt state laws that do not conform to these agreements. The statute also imposes restrictions on any U.S. legal action in response to WTO dispute rulings involving state law. The URAA allows the United States to challenge state laws domestically if they are inconsistent with the Uruguay Round Agreements. Any U.S. legal action in response to WTO dispute rulings involving state law is restricted, and private remedies are prohibited. Private remedies are prohibited under Section 102(c)(1) of the URAA, which states that only the United States can take legal action against actions inconsistent with the Uruguay Round Agreements. Congress intends to occupy the field with respect to any cause. Congress has prohibited private remedies under the URAA, stating that only the United States can take legal action against actions inconsistent with the Uruguay Round Agreements. This is intended to occupy the field with respect to any cause of action or defense related to the agreements. The URAA prohibits private parties from bringing actions against States or political subdivisions based on judgments obtained by the United States under the Uruguay Round Agreements. This provision also prevents private parties from challenging government actions under other laws. The URAA prohibits private parties from bringing actions against States or political subdivisions based on judgments obtained by the United States under the Uruguay Round Agreements. This provision also prevents private parties from challenging government actions under other laws, emphasizing the responsibility of the Federal Government to ensure consistency with U.S. obligations. The House Ways and Means Committee report emphasizes that private citizens cannot bring actions against States or political subdivisions based on judgments obtained under the Uruguay Round Agreements. The responsibility for ensuring consistency with U.S. obligations lies with the Federal Government, not private individuals. Section 102(c) allows government agencies to consider whether their actions are consistent with the agreements, but any changes must be authorized by domestic law. The Uruguay Round Agreements Act requires government agencies to ensure their actions are consistent with WTO decisions, authorized by domestic law. Section 123 and 129 of the URAA outline procedures for regulatory modifications and new determinations in trade remedy proceedings. In some cases, both provisions may be used for implementation. Section 123(g) of the URAA states that if a WTO panel finds an inconsistency in an administrative regulation, it cannot be changed without consulting Congress, seeking advice, and allowing public comment. Section 123(g) of the URAA requires consultation with Congress, private sector advice, publication in the Federal Register for public comment, and final rule publication before amending regulations. It also mandates a 60-day consultation period with Congress, allowing committees to vote on proposed actions. This does not apply to regulations of the U.S. International Trade Commission. The URAA Section 123(g) requires consultation with Congress, private sector advice, and public comment before amending regulations. Committees may vote on proposed actions during a 60-day consultation period. Section 129 outlines procedures for implementing adverse WTO reports in U.S. safeguards, antidumping, and countervailing duty proceedings. The Department of Commerce implements adverse WTO panel and Appellate Body reports in U.S. safeguards, antidumping, and countervailing duty proceedings. USITC investigates increased imports causing serious injury to domestic industries in safeguards proceedings. The USITC conducts investigations to determine if increased imports cause serious injury to domestic industries. If injury is found, the President may restrict imports or take other measures to help U.S. firms. Antidumping and countervailing duty investigations can also be initiated. The President may restrict imports or take measures to help U.S. firms if injury is found from increased imports. Antidumping and countervailing duty investigations can be initiated by petition or Department of Commerce motion. DOC determines if products are sold below fair value, while USITC determines if imports cause injury to domestic industry. The USITC investigates if products are dumped or subsidized, causing injury to domestic industry. Antidumping duties are imposed if dumping and injury are found, while countervailing duties are imposed if subsidization and injury are found. Section 129 requires action upon an adverse WTO decision. In the event of an adverse WTO decision, Section 129 requires agencies to determine compliance under existing law. The USTR may request a "Section 129 Determination" to align with WTO findings. The agency issues a determination known as a "Section 129 Determination" to align with WTO findings. If an antidumping or countervailing duty order is no longer supported by an injury determination, the USTR can direct the DOC to revoke the order. The USTR may direct DOC to revoke an antidumping or countervailing duty order if a new determination finds no material injury or threat from dumped or subsidized imports. The new DOC finding can result in adjustments to duties or even revocation of the order. Section 129 determinations apply to unliquidated goods. The Department of Commerce (DOC) may revoke an antidumping or countervailing duty order if dumping or subsidization is no longer found or is at a de minimis level. Section 129 determinations apply to unliquidated goods entering the US for consumption after specified dates, based on USITC injury determinations or new DOC findings directed by the USTR. The USTR directs the Commerce Department to revoke antidumping or countervailing duty orders when no longer supported. Section 129 determinations are reviewable in court or before binational panels. Non-implemented determinations are not subject to review. Section 129 determinations under NAFTA are not subject to judicial or binational panel review if not implemented. Private rights of action based on Uruguay Round agreements are precluded, but WTO panel findings have been brought to federal courts in challenges to agency determinations in antidumping and countervailing duty proceedings. Federal courts have jurisdiction over challenges to agency determinations in antidumping and countervailing duty proceedings under Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930. The U.S. Court of International Trade (USCIT) hears these cases, with appeals going to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit and potentially the U.S. Supreme Court. The U.S. Court of International Trade (USCIT) has jurisdiction over civil actions under Section 516A, with appeals to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit and potentially the U.S. Supreme Court. Federal courts must find agency determinations unlawful if unsupported by substantial evidence or not in accordance with law, using a two-step analysis outlined by the U.S. Supreme Court in Chevron, U.S.A. The court uses a two-step analysis outlined in Chevron, U.S.A. to determine if an agency's determination is in accordance with the law. If Congress has not clearly spoken on the issue, the court will defer to the agency's reasonable interpretation of the statute. The court uses a two-step analysis outlined in Chevron, U.S.A. to determine if an agency's determination is in accordance with the law. If the underlying statute is silent or ambiguous, the court decides whether the agency's construction of the statute is permissible and will defer to an agency's interpretation of a statute provided it is reasonable. The court may also consider applying the canon of construction from Murray v. Schooner Charming Betsy to interpret statutes consistently with U.S. international obligations. The Charming Betsy canon guides that statutes should be interpreted consistently with U.S. international obligations, specifically provisions of WTO agreements. This argument comes into play when a statute is unclear, but if the statute is unambiguous, the statutory language prevails. The underlying cause of action in legal challenges to agency actions is based on the Tariff Act. In legal challenges to agency actions, courts have not seen Section 102(c) of the URAA as preventing them from considering WTO-based arguments. Some federal courts view WTO decisions as persuasive but not binding on the United States, U.S. agencies, or the judiciary. Some federal courts view WTO decisions as persuasive but not binding on the United States, U.S. agencies, or the judiciary, with questions of compliance falling within the executive branch's jurisdiction. Courts do not base their decisions on WTO rulings when assessing agency actions. The executive branch of the United States is responsible for complying with adverse WTO decisions, and courts do not base their rulings on WTO decisions when assessing agency actions. The interaction of Chevron and Charming Betsy often arises in court cases challenging Commerce Department antidumping determinations involving "zeroing" practices. Charming Betsy frequently arises in court cases challenging Commerce Department antidumping determinations involving "zeroing," a practice that has been successfully challenged in WTO dispute settlement proceedings. U.S. courts, using the Chevron standard of review, have held that the U.S. antidumping statute does not comply with WTO rules. The U.S. antidumping statute's zeroing practice has been challenged in WTO disputes, but U.S. courts have allowed it under the Chevron standard. The Commerce Department has abandoned zeroing in original investigations and proposed changes for future antidumping proceedings. The Commerce Department has abandoned zeroing in original antidumping investigations and proposed modifications for future proceedings. In cases where antidumping orders have been challenged in WTO proceedings, new antidumping determinations have been made without zeroing, leading to amendments or revocations of the orders. Legislation introduced in recent Congresses reflects concerns about WTO decisions. The Commerce Department has stopped using zeroing in antidumping investigations and made new antidumping determinations without zeroing, resulting in amendments or revocations of orders. Recent legislation reflects concerns about WTO decisions on U.S. trade remedies. Recent legislation addressed concerns about WTO decisions on U.S. trade remedies, specifically focusing on cases involving zeroing in antidumping proceedings. The legislation aimed to comply with WTO disputes challenging the U.S. use of zeroing and its response to the WTO decisions.
